p.hi:
THE SCIENTIFIC EXPERIMENTS IN CUBA IN 1900-1901 BY THE WALTER REED
BOARD WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON THE COST OF THE EXPERIMENTS TO THE
UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT.

div1.p:
The Secretary of War, Hon. Elihu Root, in his annual report, 1902,
said with reference to the conquest of yellow fever in Cuba in
1900-1901, as follows:

“The brilliant character of this scientific achievement,
its inestimable value to mankind, the saving of thousands
of lives, and the deliverance of the Atlantic seacoast
from constant apprehension, demand special recognition
from the Government of the United States.”

The Congress had, in concurrence with his opinion, by an act
approved February 28, 1929, authorized and directed the Secretary
of War to publish annually in the Army Register a Roll of Honor
on which shall be carried the following names, and to define in
the yellow fever investigation in Cuba. The same act provided
that a gold medal be presented to each person named in the roll,
or to the representatives of those who died.

The law incorporated on the Roll of Honor the names of all of
the volunteers so that it would not be possible for other claimants
to receive consideration as a volunteer since there could be no
other available written proof. After this law was passed, many
men who were in Cuba at the time and who actually worked with the
Reed Board have tried to be placed on the Roll of Honor. All
have failed however since none could produce the necessary
evidence that he had volunteered or that he had taken the
hazardous tests.

div1.p:
MY PROBLEM: HOW MUCH DID THE REED BOARD SPEND IN ACCOMPLISHING
THE EXPERIMENT ON THE TRANSMISSION OF YELLOW FEVER BY MOSQUITOES?

This “puzzle” was put to me by Dr. Philip S. Hench and from the
data available to me, I could not have written a very valuable
cost analysis of this great experiment. However, when Dr. Hench
sent me a synopsis of the information on the stubs of the check-
book used to disburse the funds which General Wood had allotted
for gratuities and other expenses at Camp Lazear, it was a delight
to me to work out this little “puzzle”. Dr. Hench thought that
my knowledge of the men whom I had recommended to Major Reed for
various duties at Camp Lazear would help to unravel some of the
meager details on the stubs of the checkbook. And so it turned
out to be. The brief notations on the stubs contain a wealth
of information that will add much to Dr. Hench's great collection
of facts. He has been pursuing data of this kind for twelve or
fifteen years. It has been a great privilege for me to work with
him and to suggest places where original data might be found
after fifty years. I hope that my efforts are pleasing to my
friend, the fact-finding, medical historian.

I shall first submit my draft of this effort to Mr. Paul L. Tate
of Berkeley, California, for his criticism and help in untangling
anything in the “puzzle” which he may discover as desirable.
Mr. Tate was one of the efficient hospital clerks at the Columbia
Barracks Hospital at the time Walter Reed was there conducting
the yellow fever experiments. His help will add much to my
efforts. Some of the figures herein will be absolutely correct
due to the factual data from the checkbook; but others, will
have to be estimated. With Mr. Tate's help, we should be quite
accurate in our estimates since we know from the checkbook the
costs of supplies and labor in Cuba in 1900.

The Governor General's allotment for this experiment was $10,000.
The Chief Surgeon of the Department of Western Cuba, Major
Jefferson Randolph Kean, was made custodian of the fund. In
November, 1900, he promptly opened an account with the North
American Trust Company and deposited $5,000. Construction of
two small buildings was begun on November 10 (Buildings No. 1
and No. 2) and checks in payment for building materials, labor,
etc. were made out late in November and early December.

Camp Lazear was opened on November 20, 1900. The enlisted men from
our Hospital Detachment, according to orders from Headquarters,
reported to Major Reed for duty. They immediately pitched hospital
tents over the floors which had been placed on the three sites
selected by Reed.

Camp Lazear had a Headquarters Section of about 10 tents and there
the men were placed in quarantine before taking the tests. Acting
Hospital Steward Claude M. Cook, an immune, was placed in charge of
the quarantine matters. He was a most efficient and faithful non-
commissioned officer. He had become an immune from an attack of
yellow fever when at Guanajay in July, 1900, while I was in command
of that Hospital. Cook had two or three immune enlisted men to help
him in this work. Major Reed, in his Baltimore address, had this to
say of the men of this detachment (Senate Document, page 97.)

“Placed in an open field, which was fairly swept at all times by
the prevalent winds, and having a military garrison each of whose
members had been personally selected by reason of former good con-
duct and interest in the work to be here undertaken, no difficulty
whatever was experienced in maintaining the strictest quarantine
against the outside”.

I have always been proud of those men who endured the hardships of
the early days of the Spanish American War and then later passed
through the yellow fever epidemics of Quemados and Havana in 1900.
It is most gratifying to have the opportunity of noting that Major
Reed found them efficient and heroic also.

Besides the Headquarters Section, the main part of Camp Lazear, there
were also two small, specially constructed buildings, as described in
Senate Document, pg. 97. These buildings were about 75 yards from
the main camp and 80 yards from each other on opposite slopes of a
small valley. Building No. 1 was the “fomite” building and Building
No. 2 was known as the “infected mosquito” building. Near by the
“fomite” building was a tent where the occupants could get fresh
air in the daytime and also make up for sleep lost at night in the
foul surroundings and bad ventilation of the “fomite” building.

The list of names of the heroic volunteers on pages 1 and 2 of this
paper does not include the individual citations in order that we may
display after each name the actual entries from the checkbook just as
they occurred at Camp Lazear in 1900-1901, and each test with dates
and results. On the Roll of Honor, the names appear alphabetically
while here the names are listed chronologically. (See pages 10-14.)
Here then, are the actual facts just as they were recorded at the
time they occurred, over 50 years ago. These unique entries in the
checkbook will, I think, be of much interest. Reed's careful planning
and the help he received from the Governor General in the way of
advice, encouragement, and funds, were of primary importance in solv-
ing these experiments.

That the Board fully appreciated this timely help is fully acknowledged
by Reed in the Board's “Additional Note”: “We desire to here express
our sincere thanks to the Military Governor of the island of Cuba,
Maj. Gen. Leonard Wood, United States Volunteers, without whose
approval and assistance these observations could not have been carried
out.”

From here on quotations from the stubs will be grouped together and
comment made as to my interpretations of anything which is not clear.

div1.p:
Comment: This I can not, of course, unravel as no names are
mentioned.

Early in November, 1900, a large ship from Spain came to Havana
with many young Spaniards who wanted to settle in Cuba. Reed
became interested at once with the idea that this might be an
opportunity to convince the young men that this would prove to
be a favorable chance to become immune, and also add to their
funds by volunteering to take a mosquito bite. Reed promptly
consulted General Wood who conferred with the Spanish Consul.
He gave his approval of this idea if his countrymen were of
legal age.

Note check no. 16 in which F. Argilagos was paid for contracting
for Spanish labor (subjects for experiments) and check no. 19 to
Dr. Agramonte for $11.89 for immigration dues and transportation
for 8 men.

The Kean checkbook has been of great assistance, especially in
determining the importance of the part played by the few faithful
immigrants who remained at the Camp to the end. Four out of five
of them contracted yellow fever and they all took part in several
minor but important tests. There has been very little publicity
about them or what they did. The Senate Document (No. 822) gives
a few of their names and has a very incomplete record of some of
their tests. I have seen very little information regarding them,
even their names were rarely used. But here in this small check-
book are all their names, the amounts paid them and dates. One
error is, however, evident as Jose Martinez is shown by the Table,
Page 104, Senate Document No. 887, to have taken the (mosquito)
test on January 3, 1901, but there is no record of any payment of
his $200 for contracting yellow fever. There is, however, a record
of the payment of $50 to Martinez for another test. I believe the
check for Jose Fernandez, No. 48 for $200, was for Jose Martinez
and that the error was promptly corrected locally. I find that the
name of Jose Fernandez does not appear as having taken any test
but that Nicomar Fernandez took the mosquito test and received his
$200 (See check no. 25, Dec. 26.)

One of the most interesting of the minor tests in which the Spaniards
participated is disclosed by the checkbook. This makes clear the
incomplete record in the footnote, Page 82, Senate Document No. 887.

In this very interesting test, Kissinger, Moran, Jose Martinez, and
Antonio Benigno were the “controls”. The blood was obtained from an
experimental case (Andrus) whose disease was in turn produced by the
injection of 5 c.c. of blood derived from a non-experimental case of
yellow fever. The “controls” had taken the mosquito tests in December
at Camp Lazear and all had yellow fever and were treated by Dr. Ames.
They “were also injected sub-cutaneously with 1 c.c. of the same blood
without manifesting any symptoms whatever. Martinez and Benigno were
given checks for $50 each (check nos. 59 and 60) for taking this test.

div1.p:
Comments: In Table VII, Presedo, Benigno, N. Fernandez, and Jose
Martinez were the ones who took the test which produced yellow
fever, and they should all have received $200. In the checkbook,
however, Jose Fernandez is shown as having received $200 which
should have gone to Jose Martinez. I have therefore removed the
name of Jose Fernandez from this Table and left it in the complete
record of all original entries on the stubs on that paper. Jose
Fuente who received $114 for “personal experiment” was the
Spaniard who took the complete test but it was probably negative
and he would therefore get but $100 for that and $14 for labor.
Walter Reed was not impressed with the reliability of the immi-
grants who at first came to the camp as so many of them left him
without paying any attention to their agreement, but as has been
shown here, the ones who had started the tests were most reliable,
valuable as well as brave. It is not known whether they were
given a written statement of the agreement, which probably promised
to give each one of them $200 for taking the infected mosquito bite,
provided it produced yellow fever, or $100 if they took the test
and it was negative, i.e., because he was immune. Besides the
rewards, they received their subsistence and shelter at the Camp.

div1.p:
Comment: The men listed above were nearly all volunteers assigned
to the camp by Department orders. They were assigned to special
duties such as ambulance driver, guards in charge of the men who
were quarantined before their tests, cooks, etc. For these
services they were paid small sums as shown above. This improved
morale, kept the men busy, and in general produced splendid results.
Men, qualified along certain lines, such as clerks, were paid
accordingly, but the most of them received 50 cents per day.
Quarantine duty was especially important as shown in the Board's
“additional note.” Lambert probably assisted Dr. Ames at the
Camp in some way before yellow fever cases required him at the
hospital. McConnell was an artist from the S.G.O. who was sent
to make sketches of Aedes mosquitoes.

Besides the men listed above, Acting Steward Burton was the non-
commissioned officer who was in charge while the Camp was under
construction. Also Dr. Roger P. Ames was at Camp Headquarters in
general charge when Reed was not there. He had an assistant, Con-
tract Surgeon _ _ Masouri (?) who remained at Columbia Barracks
Hospital where he assisted Ames in the care of the sick yellow fever
patients. On one or two serious cases, female nurses were employed
at Columbia Barracks Hospital, but usually Ames preferred to have
Lambert and his men do the nursing.
Mazzuri
The Tests at Columbia Barracks in August and September, 1900.

By August 1900, the Board had finished its work on the Sanarelli's
organism and Lazear started his work on Dr. Finlay's Mosquito Theory.
Major Reed was suddenly called to Washington to help Dr. Victor
Vaughan close up their volumnious report on typhoid fever. Carroll
was working on his assigned duties, the intestinal flora.

On August 11, Dr. Lazear started his inoculations with two cases,
two more on August 12, and so on until on August 31, Dr. Carroll
who had been bitten with one of Lazear's mosquitoes on the w25th
of August suddenly developed a severe case of yellow fever. This
sudden and quite unexpected event resulted in the following three
cases, probably all experimental, of the Board's Preliminary Report,

div1.p:
These experiments convinced Reed, the only member then on the job,
that by establishing an isolated and well-organized camp that it
could be proven that the mosquito was responsible for transmitting
yellow fever to man.

list.item:
1. Carroll, Dr. James B. He was bitten by one of Lazear's infected
mosquitoes on August 27, 1900 at the Hospital, Columbia Barracks.
He developed a very severe case of yellow fever. This was the first
case of experimental yellow fever. No gratuity.

2. Dean (XY) 7th Cav. He was also bitten by one of Lazear's
mosquitoes August 31, 1900. Developed a mild case of yellow fever.
No gratuity.

3. Lazear, Jesse W. Was bitten by a mosquito about the middle of
September, 1900. He developed a severe case of yellow fever and
died on September 25th, the only fatality in these experiments.
It was the consensus of opinion among the doctors at the Hospital
that Lazear infected himself with one of his own mosquitoes and
thereby kept his agreement with Reed and the other non-immune
members of the Board, just as Carroll had done, i.e., took the test.

div1.p:
So, on November 20, 1900, Camp Lazear was opened and experiments
promptly began.

A fund of $10,000 was authorized by Governor General Wood to pay
gratuities and to meet the other necessary expenses. Major Kean,
the Chief Surgeon of the Department, was made Custodian. He promptly
opened a checking account with the North American Trust Company in
Havana. The first checks were drawn on November 24, 1900. By
December 26, it became necessary to decide how the gratuities should
be given out and to whom.

It was quite clear by that date that fomites played no part in the
transmission of yellow fever. Therefore, the first checks were
drawn on that date paying Kissinger, who was then convalescent from
mosquito-borne yellow fever, the first experimental case at Camp
Lazear.

Dr. Cooke and the two other men were released from confinement in
their foul surroundings in the infected bedding building at about
the same time, without contracting yellow fever, and their gratuities
had to be decided upon. The fomite test now was reduced 50 percent
for that hazard, while the mosquito test increased in value. Dr. Cooke
refused his gratuity but all of the other men accepted their $100
reward for a very trying ordeal.

It was most fortunate that General Kean had preserved the checkbook
with its stubs and recently had transferred it to Dr. Hench for
permanently placing it with other valuable documents of this fascin-
ating story of the yellow fever episode. The stubs contain informa-
tion of much value which will be carefully studied by historians.
From this book, it is now clear to me how the gratuities were awarded
as heretofore very little was definitely known about this matter.
It seems now from various notations on the stubs that there was
hesitation in Reed's mind about saying much about the tests since
General Wood and the Board had been severely attacked by some Havana
newspapers about the use of human beings in such experiments. Now
there need be no such hesitation as so much good news followed
skepticism.

On December 26, Kissinger received his check for $150 - and on
the same day another for $50 - thus making his total for the
test $200. Did Kean and Reed decide at that time to raise the
gratuity to the same amount as had been offered to the Spaniards?
I think so.

The remark on Kean's check stub was “for service”. After that,
the remarks were changed to “Personal Experiment” or to “Personal
Service”. The checks for labor were so marked or the kind of
labor performed as specified, such as “cook”.

It was also decided that the volunteer who took the mosquito test
(or blood injection test) and did not contract yellow fever should
receive but one-half of the gratuity, or $100.

In Table IX I have used the term “gratuities” to avoid confusion.
The original wording is shown elsewhere.

In October 1901, the last three experiments were carried out at Camp Columbia
by Dr, Carroll, after Camp Lazear had been closed. So far as known,
gratuities were not given.

While some of the men who took this test are shown above, it seems best
to place them all together here and then Table IX will have all of the
men who took these tests complete.

div1.p:
Springer was an all round good man that I knew very well and I
recommended him for duty at the Camp. He did not, I think, volunteer
for any of the hazardous tests but was given a gratuity of $100 for
some test such as Hospital Steward Neate took, viz. a bite by a
culex pungens that had been fed on a case of yellow fever. I
think that Major Reed felt that he must confirm Neate's experi-
ment, and therefore selected Springer.

div1.p:
The expenses in establishing Camp Lazear and running it under strict
quarantine regulations required quite a large personnel and increased
expenses in many ways that were not required in the well-established
Hospital at Columbia Barracks. Hence in estimating the cost of the
three cases at Columbia Barracks in August and September 1900, we
can eliminate practically everything but the care of the sick and
minor incidental expenses. In my estimation, $300 would amply
cover everything including funeral expenses of Dr. Lazear and the
later reburial at Baltimore, Maryland.

Comparing this estimate with the cost of $564 for 3 cases at
Camp Lazear, I believe that $300 is a far more logical figure
and would be ample.

The three cases at Columbia Barracks Hospital in October, 1901, were
treated at one time by Dr. Carroll under the very simple and
perfect conditions of that well-established hospital. No compli-
cations arose and all three patients recovered promptly. My
estimate of $200 would probably be too high.

Comparing this estimate with the cost of $564 for 3 cases at Camp
Lazear, I believe that $200 would still be too high. However, I
think it would be reasonable to use this figure as it is certainly
not far from the exact cost.

In the above estimates gratuities were not considered as none was
granted in the 6 cases at Columbia Barracks. If it is desired to
include gratuities it would be a simple matter to do so. Therefore,
the total cost of all the Reed Board's experiments without gratuities
was $3,508.
